importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article is updated on this date, indicating the ongoing status of the federal government shutdown, which is now on Day 21 and approaching a record duration.
This is a critical deadline for open enrollment of Obamacare plans. If subsidies lapse, premiums could double, which may pressure Democrats to negotiate or concede.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The shutdown is extending beyond the usual length and may surpass the 35-day record set during the first Trump administration. This prolonged period increases political and public scrutiny.

keyTakeAways: The federal government shutdown is now the second-longest in U.S. history, with Day 21 marking a critical point.
Despite Democrats making a popular policy demand — extending Obamacare subsidies — they are winning the public blame game, with Americans blaming Republicans more than Democrats in recent polls.
Public opinion polls show consistent blame shifting toward Republicans, including a 53%-37% margin in a CNBC poll and 50%-43% in a Reuters-Ipsos poll.

In past long shutdowns (1995–96 and 2018–19), the party making the controversial policy demand (Republicans) lost public support and eventually gave in. Now, Democrats are in a reversal of that pattern.
The extension of subsidies is widely supported — 72% of Americans and 51% of Republicans want it — making the demand politically viable.
Key consequences of the shutdown include delayed small business loans, missed paychecks for federal employees, and potential cuts to food stamp aid.

The looming premium hikes due to subsidy expiration may pressure Democrats to back down, but it could also create political momentum if Republicans fear they’ll be blamed for doubling health care costs.
Key political figures like Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene and Trump’s own pollster have warned Republicans that they might face public backlash for inaction.
Democrats may be gaining political leverage by refusing to back down, especially if they can show Republicans are blocking a popular policy.

namedEntities.name: Aaron Blake
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the author of the analysis, providing a political perspective on the shutdown and blame dynamics between parties.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The source of the article, providing a mainstream media outlet's analysis of the political situation during the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is a central figure in the blame game, claiming Democrats are losing public support, though polls show otherwise.

namedEntities.name: Marjorie Taylor Greene
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is cited as someone who has warned Republicans about the political risks of continuing the shutdown, suggesting internal party pressure.

namedEntities.name: Trump’s own pollster
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Political analyst or strategist associated with Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This entity is cited as advising Trump that Republicans may face public backlash, adding credibility to warnings about political consequences.

namedEntities.name: Republicans
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are blamed by public opinion for the shutdown, especially for making policy demands (e.g., border wall) that were unpopular.

namedEntities.name: Democrats
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are demanding extended Obamacare subsidies, a popular policy, and are currently winning public blame despite making the demand.

namedEntities.name: Obamacare
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the policy demand at the center of the political standoff, with subsidies being extended or allowed to lapse.

namedEntities.name: Enhanced Obamacare subsidies
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Government financial support for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The core of the Democratic policy demand; its extension is popular and central to the political negotiation.

namedEntities.name: Reuters-Ipsos poll
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It shows that Americans blame Republicans more than Democrats in the current shutdown, indicating a shift in public perception.

namedEntities.name: CNBC poll
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It shows a large public blame gap (53% vs. 37%) against Republicans, reinforcing the idea that blame is shifting.

namedEntities.name: KFF
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It provides data showing that health insurance premiums could double if subsidies lapse, influencing political strategy.

namedEntities.name: 1995–1996 shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Historical precedent shows that the party making a controversial policy demand lost public support and eventually gave in.

namedEntities.name: 2018–2019 shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Similar to 1995–96, Republicans made the controversial demand (border wall), lost public blame, and eventually backed down.

namedEntities.name: Open enrollment for Obamacare
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Annual period when individuals can enroll in health insurance plans
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The deadline on November 1 is pivotal because it will expose the cost of subsidy cuts — potentially doubling premiums — which may influence negotiations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The federal government shutdown, now on its 21st day and approaching a record length, is marked by a reversal of historical patterns. While historically the party making a controversial policy demand (like Republicans in past shutdowns) has lost public support and eventually given in, Democrats are currently winning the public blame game — with Americans blaming Republicans more than Democrats in recent polls. This is because Democrats are advocating for the extension of popular Obamacare subsidies, which 72% of Americans support. The upcoming open enrollment deadline on November 1 will expose the cost of subsidy cuts, potentially doubling premiums — a major political risk for Republicans. The article questions whether Democrats, despite being in a politically strong position, will back down, especially if they believe they can leverage the political fallout from premium hikes. The situation is more complex than past shutdowns due to public opinion, political stakes, and the potential for a significant political win for Democrats.
title: Could Democrats win the shutdown standoff? They’re still winning the blame game
